body.p: lymphocytes are the mediators of the adaptive immune response. Each lymphocyte has a receptor that recognizes only one epitope. This is like a lock and key system. The pathogen has a protein that is broken down into a protein fragment (peptide). This peptide is the epitope that acts like a that only fits one lock. That lock is the on the T or B cell. When the epitope is inserted into the matching receptor it initiates a series of events (turning the key) that causes the stimulated T or B cell to rapidly divide, producing many copies of itself. This process is termed .

feedback.p: Correct. T and B are the two main types of lymphocytes.
Incorrect. Granulocytes and monocytes are leukocytes but not lymphocytes.

hint.p: There are two types of lymphocytes and they are distinguished by capital letters of the alphabet, describing their maturity in thymus gland and bone marrow.

hint.p: When the epitope is inserted into the matching lock, it initiates a series of events that activate the immune response by a lymphocyte.

hint.p: When the epitope is inserted into the matching lock on the T and B lymphocyte, it initiates a series of events that activates the immune response.

Correct. This refers to cells rapidly making many copies of themselves.

hint.p: These cells are clones of the stimulated lymphocyte, and will later differentiate into effector and memory cells.
